awd_titl_txt: CICI: CSRC: Research Security Operations Center (ResearchSOC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Research Security Operations Center (ResearchSOC) provides the research and education (R&E) community with cybersecurity services, training, and information sharing needed to make scientific computing resilient to cyberattacks and capable of supporting trustworthy, productive research. The R&E community has particular challenges regarding cybersecurity: a large span of size and autonomy, the use of diverse infrastructure (scientific instruments, sensor networks, sequencers, etc.), the highly collaborative and dynamic nature of scientific work, and acquiring the scarce domain expertise expertise needed to support cybersecurity in the research context.

To address these challenges, the ResearchSOC leverages existing cybersecurity services from Indiana University, Duke University, the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center, and the University of California San Diego. It tailors these service to the needs of the R&E community and combines these operational services with the establishment of a community of practice for sharing knowledge and expertise, and operational intelligence. The ResearchSOC also offers outreach and training targeted at  educating research project teams and the higher education information security community regarding information security for research. The ResearchSOC is engaging with the cybersecurity research community to discern how it can advance research activities and make data available for research purposes in order to improve the overall state of the art in information security.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

The Research Security Operations Center (ResearchSOC) was funded by NSF’s Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure under the Cybersecurity Innovation for Cyberinfrastructure (CICI) program as a collaborative security response center. The ResearchSOC mission, as described in the funding NSF solicitation 18-547, is to provide expertise and resources that can be leveraged by the entire R&E community to improve the cybersecurity posture of scientific cyberinfrastructure and raise awareness of security threats facing the community.

Under NSF Grant 1840034, ResearchSOC provided NSF research facilities with the operational cybersecurity expertise and services necessary to rise to evolving cybersecurity challenges and meet their cybersecurity goals. ResearchSOC does this through providing:

  • A security operations center, via OmniSOC, that provides trusted and actionable intelligence to higher education institutions. 

  • Vulnerability identification service, leveraging the widely deployed, open source VAS framework.

  • Sharing Threat Intelligence for Network Gatekeeping with Automated Response (STINGAR), a honeypot-based security system.

  • Delivering threat intelligence alerts tailored to the scientific research community.

  • Virtual cybersecurity services to supplement security workforce within client organizations.

Intellectual Merit

ResearchSOC made anonymized operational cybersecurity data available for research and education to support the advancement of effective research and to improve education through the use of real-world data.

Broader Impacts

During the award period, ResearchSOC worked directly with six Major Facilities to understand their unique cyberinfrastructure and aid in building proactive cybersecurity controls fit to their cybersecurity programs. As modern science is reliant on computers, data, networking, and computer-enabled instruments and sensors, cyber attacks can render these devices unavailable and untrustworthy, harming the productivity, integrity, and impact of scientific research. ResearchSOC reduced the impact of these attacks and raised the detective, response, and recovery capabilities of its member organizations, ensuring productive and trusted research would be minimally hindered by security threats among its members.

Alongside the direct impact of increased operational capabilities of its members, ResearchSOC raised awareness of cybersecurity threats focused on open science and educated members of the open science research cyberinfrastructure community on best practices for prioritizing cybersecurity resources, improving incident response capacity, and developing cybersecurity expertise in-house through online webinars, conference presentations, and white papers.

ResearchSOC, now a unit of OmniSOC, continues to work with Major Facilities to improve both their own cybersecurity programs and the services offered by ResearchSOC. As ResearchSOC's capabilities have matured, additional NSF projects such as the Academic Research Fleet have begun to utilize them, which in turn provides more threat intelligence and other new insights that can be shared with both ResearchSOC members and the wider cyberinfrastructure community.
